channel.title: Digg Top Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: The Controversial Science Of Transgender Athletes In Combat Sports
item.description: Can punching someone in the face really be gender neutral?

item.title: Where Pakistani Muslims Go To Secretly Party
item.description: The Kalash people spurn Islamic law by drinking, taking drugs, and partying. So for decades, usually law-abiding Muslims have ventured into their home valleys to party with them.

item.title: Russian Daredevil Hangs On From Great Heights
item.description: Russia has proven to have an endless supply of daredevils who get a rush out of climbing sky-scraping towers and monstrous cranes, but one guy who goes by the pseudonym Mustang Wanted tempts gravity by not only scaling his lofty destination but by then hanging off of it.

item.title: 3-D Holograms On Your Phone: No Glasses Required
item.description: In theaters, 3-D movies are everywhere. But how about a 3-D holographic movie on your mobile phone?

item.title: This Lizard-Inspired Robot Can Scamper Across Sand
item.description: Designing a robot that can easily move across loose terrain—say, a rover meant to traverse the surface of Mars—poses a unique engineering challenge: Wheels commonly sink into what engineers call “flowable ground” (mixtures of sand, soil, mud and grass).

item.title: Poor-Quality Chinese Concrete Could Lead To Skyscraper Collapses
item.description: A sand scandal is brewing in China, with concerns that low-quality concrete has been used in the construction of many of the country’s largest buildings — putting them at risk of collapse.

item.title: The Wil Wheaton Story That Will Make You Sob In Your Cheerios
item.description: Last night, I was checking Facebook on my phone, when I ran across a story that many of you have may have also seen on your Facebook walls. I’m not sure what compelled me to read it, but five minutes later, my heart may have swollen 3 sizes and there was definitely something in my eye.

item.title: The Internet-Demanded, Partially Scientific Testing Of Ultra-Ever Dry
item.description: You've seen the amazing YouTube videos, right? Someone tries to wet a surface with water and it amazingly just beads up and runs off. So one reporter had to find out if the stuff really worked.

item.title: Yes, Cyberattacks Are Perfectly Legal Under The Laws Of War
item.description: The term "cyberwarfare" is meaningless in the worst way—it puts the imagination into paranoid overdrive and is not limited by any legal definitions. All the rules we’ve got on armed conflict today apply to ye olde bombs and bullets, not viruses and botnets.

item.title: Cyclist Hits Antelope, Antelope Wins
item.description: This week sees the Cape Epic, a 433-mile trek through western South Africa. During Monday's stage, Austrian Robert Mennen had a close encounter with a stupid, stupid antelope that darted out from the bush.

item.title: Is This The Last Big Gay-Marriage Fight?
item.description: Next week, the Supreme Court is expected to issue its decision on the two gay marriage cases in front of it. Either decision could legalize the practice in one quick blow. So a bumper crop of organizations and activists are weighing in now, while there's still a reason to.

item.title: What Would Life Be Like In A World Without The Internet?
item.description: Not being able to dick off at work all day? Actually talking to friends? Meeting cute strangers on the street in the course of getting directions? NOOOOOOOOOO!

item.title: Where's Voyager 1?
item.description: For about three hours on Wednesday, Voyager 1 had left the solar system — before a rewritten news release headline pulled it back in. So where exactly is it?

item.title: PETA Euthanized 90% Of The Animals In Its Shelter
item.description: Critics are charging PETA — renowned for its aggressive anti-cruelty campaigns — with hypocrisy after the group's euthanasia statistics were posted on the website of the Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services.

item.title: iPads Have Taken Over The Cockpit
item.description: The FAA has finally approved the use of the iPad Electronic Flight Bag. So what's it like to fly with an iPad in the cockpit?

item.title: Kids In Vietnam Are Crazy Good At Programming
item.description: 11th graders in Vietnam are so good at programming that they could easily pass an interview at Google.

item.title: How Background Checks For Guns Really Work
item.description: The Senate and several states are considering measures to require background checks for every firearm purchase. Here's how those checks work.

item.title: The Pot Industry's Most Politically Important Dispensary
item.description: In the eyes of the federal government, there is no such thing as “medical marijuana.” But there’s a dispensary just blocks from the Capitol.

item.title: How One Man's Makeshift Google Reader Logo Became The 'Default'
item.description: "Five years ago, I was wanting to install Google Reader on my desktop with Fluid but noticed I couldn’t find a good icon for it at all. So I made one, and posted it to Flickr."

item.title: Inside 'Apple Anonymous': The Secret Society Of Apple’s Retail Army
item.description: Even with strict, Apple Corporate-implemented policies on social media usage of its employees, a portion of Apple retail employees have formed an under-the-radar, “Apple Anonymous” community.

item.title: It Turns Out That Great White Sharks Eat Even More Than We Thought
item.description: And we already thought that they ate a lot.

item.title: The Weirdest Aircraft Of The 20th Century
item.description: The 20th Century gave us the Wright Brothers, the 747 and the Concorde. But it also gave us some of the strangest things ever to take to the skies. Here are some of the most insane aircraft ever conceived.

item.title: Why I'm Walking Every Single Block In New York City
item.description: The goal of my quest to walk every block of every street in all five boroughs in New York City is to know nothing. To tear down all the generalizations about the city and its people and its neighborhoods that I’ve absorbed without thinking during my time here.

item.title: A Surprising Map Of The Countries That Are Most And Least Welcoming To Foreigners
item.description: Buried several hundred pages into a new World Economic Forum report on global tourism, past the sections on air travel infrastructure and physician density (by which they mean the number of physicians per capita, not the mass-per-cubic-meter of individual doctors), are some very interesting numbers.

item.title: There Is One Color You Need To Wear On Your Dating Profile
item.description: If you want to stand out, this is the color you should be wearing when you take your dating selfie.

item.title: A Father-Daughter Dance — In Jail
item.description: For a few hours on this Saturday afternoon, the incarcerated fathers will be allowed to take part in an American tradition, the father-daughter dance. “A Dance of Their Own,” thought to be the only event of its kind in the country, will be in the jail’s small, windowless multipurpose room.

item.title: New 'Star Trek Into Darkness' Trailer Shows Off Homicidal Cumberbatch
item.description: The latest 'Stark Trek Into Darkness' trailer focuses on a very determined and very evil Benedict Cumberbatch.

item.title: British Airways To Hold A Hackathon At 34,000 Feet
item.description: British Airways is inviting 100 guests to participate in an 11-hour hackathon during a transatlantic flight from San Francisco to London.

item.title: This Woman Is The Ultimate Woman-Hater
item.description: Meet Claire Khaw, a British “anti-feminist” who wants nothing more than to “restore the patriarchy by means of establishing a one-party theocracy based on the Koranic principles that will replace the immorality of feminism.”

item.title: 35 Facts About Mr. Rogers
item.description: The beloved Fred Rogers would have been 85 yesterday. In celebration, here are 35 facts that you probably didn't know about him.

item.title: Can You Train Yourself To Get By On Less Sleep?
item.description: Margaret Thatcher did it. So did Salvador Dali. They survived the day with only a few hours of sleep. The question is whether you can force yourself to do the same.
